channel.title: Posts on t0rsten.github.io
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on t0rsten.github.io

item.title: [PS Snippet] Get OS Version
item.description: Fast way to get the Operating System Version [Environment]::OSVersion #Output Platform ServicePack Version VersionString -------- ----------- ------- ------------- Win32NT 10.0.18363.0 Microsoft Windows NT 10.0.18363.0
item.content:
Fast way to get the Operating System Version

[Environment]::OSVersion

#Output
Platform ServicePack Version      VersionString
-------- ----------- -------      -------------
 Win32NT             10.0.18363.0 Microsoft Windows NT 10.0.18363.0

item.title: [PS Snippet] Adding leading zero
item.description: Adding leading zero with -f operator. 2..20 | foreach {'Folder_{0:D2}' -f $_}
item.content:
Adding leading zero with -f operator.

2..20 | foreach {'Folder_{0:D2}' -f $_}

item.title: [PS Snippet] Find Last Reboot
item.description: Find the last reboot. Get-EventLog -LogName System -ComputerName $Env:COMPUTERNAME | Where-Object { $_.eventid -eq '1074' } | sort -Descending -Property timegenerated | Select-Object -First 1 -Property MachineName, Username, timegenerate
item.content:
Find the last reboot.

Get-EventLog -LogName System -ComputerName $Env:COMPUTERNAME | Where-Object { $_.eventid -eq '1074' } | sort -Descending -Property timegenerated | Select-Object -First 1 -Property MachineName, Username, timegenerate

item.title: Powershell Array Fundamentals
item.description: Arrays are a fundamental feature. Arrays make it possible to ingest, manipulate and output true data structures (and not just raw strings). Arrays can contain one or more elements. An element can be a string, an integer, an object, or even another array, and one array can contain any combination of these elements. Create an Array # create an empty array $cities = @() # create an array with items $cities = @('Toronto','Ottawa','Vancouver','Edmonton','Winnipeg') An array has a length propertie which we can use to get the number of elements in the array
item.content:
Arrays are a fundamental feature. Arrays make it possible to ingest, manipulate and output true data structures (and not just raw strings).

Arrays can contain one or more elements. An element can be a string, an integer, an object, or even another array, and one array can contain any combination of these elements.

Create an Array

# create an empty array
$cities = @()

# create an array with items
$cities = @('Toronto','Ottawa','Vancouver','Edmonton','Winnipeg')

An array has a length propertie which we can use to get the number of elements in the array

# get number of items
$cities.Lenth

# Output
5

Accessing Items

There are several ways to access items of an array.

# return all items
$cities

# Output
Toronto
Ottawa
Vancouver
Edmonton
Winnipeg

An array has a position index that refers to the elements.

# return item on position 2
$cities[1]

# Output
Ottawa

# return multiple items
$cities[0,2,4]

# Output
Toronto
Vancouver
Winnipeg

# return the last item in the array. The negative number tells to count backward.
$cities[-2]

# Output
Edmonton

Accessing Items - Iteration

Another usful way to access items is looping through the array.

# return all items
$cities | Foreach-Object { $_ }

# Output
Toronto
Ottawa
Vancouver
Edmonton
Winnipeg

# another way to return all items
foreach ($city in $cities)
{
  Write-Output $city
}

# Output
Toronto
Ottawa
Vancouver
Edmonton
Winnipeg

Add or Remove Items

Add or Remove Items of an array should be simple, but it isn’t. The default type, an object array (System.Object[]), has a fixed size. It’s easy to change objects, but you can’t add or remove them.

# create an array with items
$cities = @('Toronto','Ottawa','Vancouver','Edmonton','Winnipeg')

$cities.IsFixedSize

# Output
True

Add or Remove will faild


$cities.Add('Elmira')

Exception calling "Add" with "1" argument(s): "Collection was of a fixed size."
At line:1 char:1
+ $cities.Add('Elmira')
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [], MethodInvocationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NotSupportedException

$cities.Remove('Ottawa')

Exception calling "Remove" with "1" argument(s): "Collection was of a fixed size."
At line:1 char:1
+ $cities.Remove('Ottawa')
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [], MethodInvocationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NotSupportedException

The common solution to add Items to an array is the += operator.

# Add a Item
$cities += 'Elmira'

# Output
$cities

Toronto
Ottawa
Vancouver
Edmonton
Winnipeg
Elmira

The similar solution to remove Items from a array should be the -= operator. Far from it!

$cities -= 'Elmira'
Method invocation failed because [System.Object[]] does not contain a method named 'op_Subtraction'.
At line:1 char:1
+ $cities -= 'Elmira'
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (op_Subtraction:String) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : MethodNotFound

Now i will show some solution that works. One way to remove an object is to create a new array that includes only selected objects from the original array.

$cities = $cities | Where-Object { $_ -ne 'Elmira' }

# Output
$cities

Toronto
Ottawa
Vancouver
Edmonton
Winnipeg

You can also use the index notation to exclued objects.

$cities = $cities[0,1,3]

# Output
$cities

Toronto
Ottawa
Edmonton

item.title: [PS Snippet] Remove Leading Null From IP Address
item.content:
# Solution 1
'172.010.024.101' -replace '\b0+\B'

# Solution 2
[System.Net.IPAddress]$ip = '172.010.024.101'
$ip.IPAddressToString

item.title: [PS Snippet] Restore Default Powershell Gallery Repository
item.description: This will restore the default repository Register-PSRepository -Default
item.content:
This will restore the default repository

Register-PSRepository -Default

item.title: [PS Snippet] Monitor the latest changes of a file (tail equivalent)
item.description: Get-Content -Path C:\Windows\System32\dhcp\DhcpSrvLog-fri.log -Tail 20 -Wait -tail will display the latest 20 lines of the file and -wait to see updates in real time.
item.content:
Get-Content -Path C:\Windows\System32\dhcp\DhcpSrvLog-fri.log -Tail 20 -Wait

-tail will display the latest 20 lines of the file and -wait to see updates in real time.

item.title: [PS Snippet] Identify Leap Year
item.content:
Identify a leap year:

[datetime]::IsLeapYear(2008)
#True
[datetime]::IsLeapYear(2009)
#False

item.title: [PS Snippet] Get system uptime
item.description: Get system uptime, the elapsed time since last restart. [Timespan]::FromMilliseconds([Environment]::TickCount)
item.content:
Get system uptime, the elapsed time since last restart.

[Timespan]::FromMilliseconds([Environment]::TickCount)

item.title: [PS Snippet] Get RAM
item.description: Get total size of RAM installed. [Math]::Round((Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem).TotalPhysicalMemory/1GB)
item.content:
Get total size of RAM installed.

[Math]::Round((Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem).TotalPhysicalMemory/1GB)

item.title: [PS Snippet] Get Current User and Machine
item.content:
# current user
[Environment]::UserDomainName + "\" + [Environment]::UserName
# current machine
[Environment]::MachineName

item.title: [PS Snippet] Difference Between Break and Continue
item.description: The difference between break and continue. break exit a loop or switch statement. continue continue but skips the current iteration. switch (2,4,5) { 1 {"One"} 2 {"Two"; continue} 3 {"Three"} 4 {"Four"; break} 5 {"Five"} } Output Two Four
item.content:
The difference between break and continue.

  • break exit a loop or switch statement.
  • continue continue but skips the current iteration.
switch (2,4,5)
{
  1 {"One"}
  2 {"Two"; continue}
  3 {"Three"}
  4 {"Four"; break}
  5 {"Five"}
}

Output

Two
Four

item.title: [PS Snippet] Convert String to DateTime
item.description: Convert a string to a date-time object. [Datetime]::ParseExact('02/04/1984', 'MM/dd/yyyy', $null)
item.content:
Convert a string to a date-time object.

[Datetime]::ParseExact('02/04/1984', 'MM/dd/yyyy', $null)
